title: Sans with sheared terminals?
content:
What are people's recommendations for some (non-crazy)  
sans fonts with terminals sheared non-horizonally/vertically\*?  
Flare-serif fonts can apply too.

\* Not non-perpendicularly as I previously mis-wrote.

hhp
author: hrant

comments.content:
You mean like [Finnegan](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.linotype.com/de/1034/finnegan-schriftfamilie.html) ?  
(Sorry for self-promoting)
FF Supergrotesk

CORRECTION (edited above):  
I'm not looking for shears that are non-perpendicular (implicitly to  
the "stroke"), I'm looking for shears that are non-horizontal/vertical.  
So perpendicular is even OK - although not required. (You might have  
figured all this out already...)

Jürgen, Finnegan is a valid suggestion (with no need to apologize).  
Supergrotesk: nope, the shears are generally horizontal/vertical.

A good example of what I'm looking for is H&FJ Whitney.

hhp
ITC Quay Sans
FF Profile and FF Enzo, formerly known here as Zai
So you're looking for a humanist sans? The possibilities are endless.

Actually it doesn't have to be humanist. I'm looking for sans fonts where the terminals are cut at "funny" angles, like Profile. Quay Sans is a great font (takes after papa Syntax), it's über-humanist, and it even has flares, but it doesn't really qualify.

hhp
Try [Kabel](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.paratype.com/fstore/default.asp?fcode=236&search=Kabel).
Dwiggins' [Metro](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/metro-2/familytree.html)?

Plantago:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322im_/http:/typophile.com/files/plantago_3608.jpg)
  
maybe the terminals are too funny?

Would [Magma](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.stonetypefoundry.com/magmaoverview.html) by [Sumner Stone](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Sumner%20Stone) qualify?

Make Gill Sans the way Gill drew it?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322im_/http:/typophile.com/files/EG%20Gill%20Sans%20262%20lc%20drwg%20-%20det%20450_5411.jpg)

Hrant,  
what about [GST Polo](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.typemanufactur.com/Frameset_1.html) by Georg Salden then?

(you have to search after \>Fonts after style \>Sans Serif \>GST Polo; i believe the pictures of the English version of the website are not working, so you have to browse through the German version \>Fonts nach Stil \>Sans Serif \>GST Polo)

And as those images are tiny anyway, have a look at this thread for links to useful samples of GST Polo:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/32095](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/typophile.com/node/32095 "http://typophile.com/node/32095")
[Le Monde Sans?](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/LeMondeSans)

"What are people’s recommendations for some (non-crazy)  
sans fonts with terminals sheared non-horizonally/vertically\*?  
Flare-serif fonts can apply too."

What 4?

Cheers!
I hope I will also be forgiven for self-promotion, but [Anivers](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.josbuivenga.demon.nl/anivers.html) came into my mind reading this topic.

What about Jeremy Tankard's Stephenson, Blake & Co. inspired [Wayfarer](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.typography.net/type/wayfarer.htm). That has some of the most arbitrary lower case terminals you'll ever see. Check page 3 of [this pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.typography.net/info/Wayfarer_Sample_Book.pdf).

I think that Ricardo Santos Lisboa might fit you purposes: [http://www.vanarchiv.com/lisboa-introduction.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131226005322/http:/www.vanarchiv.com/lisboa-introduction.html "http://www.vanarchiv.com/lisboa-introduction.html")

Dino
@Margor - Where did you find Plantago? Are you sure that's what it's called, I googled it but came up with nothing.
